text: the mood at the rescue camp has changed
completely from a deepening gloom to
wild celebrations but now what's needed
is a cool-headed plan to get the boys
and their coach out and there are no
easy options the rescuers traced the
boys route up the cave system from the
entrance through a large cavern that's
now rescue command center past the place
where the team left their bikes and
further up where their bags and shoes
were found the working assumption is
that they traveled deeper into the
system to escape rising floodwaters one
part is now under more than five meters
of water further up rescuers found
prints more evidence that they were on
the right track before reaching a muddy
ledge on which the team had been
sheltering for ten days where one is to
drill through the rock to provide a new
route for the boys that's how the
Chilean miners were rescued in 2010
through a new shaft but in the time ount
ins the task is far more complex the two
challenges I think for drilling would be
to get exactly to the right place
because you have to know where to drill
and if you're drilling into a cave
passage deep relatively large one you
have to be right on the money a few
meters off and you might miss it all
together and then the other thing I
think it would be a considerable
challenge getting the equipment up to up
to the right location the second option
is to get the team back along the route
that the rescue is used to reach them
but this is narrow dark and partially
flooded it tested the expertise of some
of the world's top cave divers is it
really feasible for a group of non
swimming children to make it you're
having to convince somebody to put on
diving equipment bring them out through
a lot of flooded passage if they had a
panic attack or something in there there
is no surface to go up to the divers
have also got to lock out to their own
safety the visibility is virtually zero
and because it's the monsoon and the
caves flooded they could well be tree
trunks and bits of other debris that
have that have been washed into the
system
and the third option is to wait just as
the waters rose eventually they will
fall again but this could take several
months after the rainy season preparing
the boys for months of inactivity will
be very difficult we know a few things
can help one is dropping fluorescent
lights down into that space that are set
on timers that mimics day and night
because that's really important in
resetting their sleep patterns and
helping them get rest and sleep also
having scheduled activities planned
which might sound bizarre when you're
trapped in a cave it is really important
to keep people focused and to have a
team work that can also really help
build up resilience and hope and that's
if they can wait the authorities are
attempting to pump out the cave system
now to keep the waters down and the boys
safe but more rain could make that
impossible being in a cave in Thailand
in the wet season that you know where
they were sitting at that moment I don't
think there's anything you know they
would say that's a that is a place that
the water couldn't touch you know I have
been involved in projects you know with
with equipment measuring conditions
where where after a single rainstorm or
you know I've measured water you know
coming up 30 meters you know in a few
hour in less than 12 hours meanwhile the
parents gathered at the surface have to
wait but now at least knowing their
son's have been found the Thai
authorities are trying to establish
phone lines so they can talk to them but
this story is by no means over
